https://archive.vn/MrRUv    Today, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance, the Honourable Chrystia Freeland, and the Honourable Carla Qualtrough, Minister of Employment, Workforce Development and Disability Inclusion, announced the extension of crucial COVID-19 support measures for Canadians and Canadian businesses in recognition that uneven economic reopening across regions and sectors means workers and businesses continue to need support. These extensions include:    Extending the eligibility period for the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy, the Canada Emergency Rent Subsidy and Lockdown Support until October 23, 2021, and increasing the rate of support employers and organizations can receive during the period between August 29 and September 25, 2021.  Extending the Canada Recovery Benefit (CRB), the Canada Recovery Caregiving Benefit (CRCB), and the Canada Recovery Sickness Benefit (CRSB) until October 23, 2021.  Increasing the maximum number of weeks available for the CRB, by an additional four weeks, to a total of 54 weeks, at a rate of $300 per week, and ensuring it is available to those who have exhausted their employment insurance (EI) benefits.  As our recovery gets underway, workers and businesses in certain regions and sectors continue to need support. In the April federal budget, the government recognized that the economic and public health situation remained uncertain and made sure it had the flexibility to extend supports further into the fall as the public health situation warranted. By moving forward on these extensions, the government is ensuring that businesses – including those in hard-hit sectors like tourism, hospitality, arts, and entertainment – can continue to get the support they need so they can invest in their recovery and long-term prosperity.    In addition, the government is proposing to offer businesses greater flexibility when calculating the revenue decline used to determine eligibility for the wage and rent subsidy programs and the new Canada Recovery Hiring Program. The government is also releasing draft legislation that provides further clarity on previously announced changes to the wage subsidy for furloughed employees.

Nova Scotia remains in Phase 4 of its re-opening plan. Indoor visits can resume in a resident’s room at long-term care facilities for all residents (fully vaccinated, partially vaccinated and not vaccinated residents). Fully vaccinated residents at long-term care facilities can leave the facility to visit with family in their homes (including overnight stays). All residents can leave the facility to visit indoor and outdoor public places (like parks, stores and restaurants). Source: https://archive.fo/246JU

Due to increasing infections within the community, Northwest Territories have announced new restrictions to long-term care facilities to come into effect August 19. These restrictions apply to LTC facilities in Yellowknife, Norman Well,s and Behchoko:  - Stopping all visitations;  - Restricted passes out of facility to essential medical appointments;  - Increase staff and resident screening to twice (2) per day;  - Cleaning of high touch surfaces 4 times per day;  - No group activities (individual only); and  - Physical distancing of residents when out of their rooms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210831005240/https://www.nthssa.ca/en/newsroom/public-notice-long-term-care-facility-restrictions-across-nwt

You must be vaccinated to visit a long term care home. Masks must be worn in communal spaces and may only be taken off if you are fully vaccinated.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210823132441/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions

On 23 august 2021, New Brunswick (NB) remains at Green status: “LTC GREEN: No capacity limitations on any visitors...  Mandatory masking (community or medical mask) while travelling through facility and/or visiting in common areas. May remove when visiting with resident in private room if resident in agreement. Visitors should be strongly encouraged to wear masks continuously if they or the resident are not fully vaccinated...Encourage visitors to get vaccinated against COVID and other communicable diseases in a nondiscriminatory manner using evidence based and culturally sensitive means...Interim Transitional Measure: mandatory masking (medical grade) for all staff in resident areas/common areas (any situation or area where staff may interact or come in contact with a resident)...Foster a non-discriminatory atmosphere where staff feel comfortable to keep their distance.” While there is encouragement based on vaccination status, there are no mandatory distinctions between vaccinated and unvaccinated visitors. See Province of NB website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210823182935/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210824114939/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/h-s/pdf/Measures_RestrictionsNH_ARF.pdf

On 30 August 2021, the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL) continues to advise: “Visiting restrictions have been lifted for all  provincially operated acute care facilities, health centres and long-term care homes; as well as privately operated long-term care homes, personal care homes, and community care homes. Although restrictions are lifted, please continue to give consideration to using alternate communication methods such as virtual visits and phone calls to maintain contact with your loved ones, when possible, rather than in-person visiting...When visiting a patients/resident in a multi-bed room, visitors are reminded that physical distancing is recommended as much as possible...Individuals who are required to self-isolate [e.g., Unvaccinated Canadians are tested on day 7, 8 or 9, and self-isolate until receipt of a negative test result. See C7 notes.] are permitted to provide support/visit only in the specific situations outlined in … Section 5.1 End-of Life Visiting – All Facilities, and only in consultation with the clinical care team of the patient/resident...All visitor(s) must be screened upon arrival, prior to the visit beginning... Individuals who are feeling unwell or sick should not present for visits.” See government of NL website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210830132029/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/health-facilities/overall-guidance/
